Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Imaging System for the Study of Complex Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal is for the acquisition of a Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) system for a variety of studies involving complex fluids including investigating flows of non-Newtonian fluids, suspensions and fluid flow in complex geometries. These studies are pertinent in applications throughout biology, engineering and geophysics. The investigators who will utilize this instrument represent different disciplines within the College of Science and Mathematics and also Art & Design at Montclair State University such as Physics (Drs. Vaidya,Truitt), Applied Mathematics(Drs. Forgoston, Mukherjee, Trubatch and Yecko), Biology (Dr. Vanderklein), Computer Science (Dr. Robila ) and Photography (Prof. Schnitzer). The PIV system will be housed in and become an integral part of the Complex Fluids Lab in room 224B of the Mathematical Sciences department. The specific targets for study include (i) vortex induced oscillations, (ii) flows of ferromagnetic fluids and liquid crystals, (iii) geophysical flows and (iv) flow in plants. The PIV system will enable the PIs to obtain high quality flow data for a set of research problems where critical progress demands more information on spatial and temporal scales, obtained non-invasively. The high speed camera will provide experimentally relevant temporal tracking of flow patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant for our proposal "MRI: Acquisition of an Imaging System for the Study of Complex Fluids" resulted in the acquisition of a flow imaging system which included the Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) unit and supporting instruments such as traversing systems, cameras and additional optics for a variety of studies involving complex fluids flows of non-Newtonian fluids, suspensions and fluid flows in complex geometries. Besides advancing our understanding of the fundaments of fluid mechanics, imaging system has helped us venture into applications in areas such as sedimentology, large scale oceanic flow patterns and in energy harvesting from fluid-structure interaction.

The PIV system is housed in the Complex Fluids Lab in the Mathematical Sciences department at Montclair State University (MSU). The instruments have added a unique dimension to the ongoing research efforts in our fluid dynamics group. Their real values lies in the ability to reveal complicated flow patterns which cannot be otherwise detected by the naked eye. Flow imaging allows us to confirm and strengthen our mathematical and computational models.  Specific problems that the instruments have been used to investigate thus far include:

  1. Fluid-solid interaction: Flow past fixed and moving structures in a flow is a very complex problem and involves an understanding of the coupled interaction of fluid flows in the presence of an obstacle. Imaging techniques have allowed us to identify how a flow develops and evolves from a uniform pattern to turbulence.  We have been able to identify specific stages in the flow where the pattern shows a distinct change in structure and also in the resulting force that the flow induces upon its surroundings. Faculty and student researchers at the Complex fluids lab at MSU have been working on visualizing vortical flow patterns past rigid and flexible bodies and studying their complicated coupled dynamics. A thorough understanding of these forces permits us to apply the fundamental knowledge resulting from these studies to energy harvesting and locomotion, for instance.
  2. Geophysical flows: A team of researchers from MSU University and Cooper Union have combined experimental studies of controllable ocean-like flows with computer models of fluid flows and mathematical models of transport and control to find optimal control strategies for autonomous ocean vehicles. The methods are being used to predict a wide variety of physical processes in realistic fluid flows and to optimize the transport of robotic sensors and vehicles operating in these fluid environments. Improved flow-robot control strategies will help advance fields ranging from ocean monitoring to robotic micro-surgery.

In addition to these scientific advances these instruments have also helped in improving our educational efforts and train students in cutting edge technology. So far, in a span of three years, 3 undergraduates and 3 graduate research students have worked on the system and are helping train the next generation of students who will work with these instruments. Our current students on this project have already been co-authors on multiple peer-reviewed journal articles and presented work at national conferences. The imaging system has also been used for demonstration purposes in upper level physics courses and in specialized independent study courses with advanced students exposing this science and technology to a large body of science students.

The investigators who have utilized this instrument over the past three years represent different disciplines within the College of Science and Mathematics and also Art & Design at Montclair State University including Physics, Applied Mathematics, Biology and Photography.
